justification: The article states that "These results render the ERN a robust and reliable neural substrate of error monitoring and subsequent recruitment of cognitive control."
The ERN is described as "making the performance monitoring process observable by non-invasive techniques," linking this construct to the ERN measure.
Negative and unexpected feedback "elicits the feedback-related negativity (FRN)… the FRN… obeying to necessary and sufficient criteria of a reward prediction error (RPE) signal."
During conflict "an increased frontocentral negativity in the EEG is observable (N2)," identifying N2 as the electrophysiological index of response conflict.
Time–frequency analyses revealed that "conflict and error processing coincide with increased midfrontal theta-band (4-8 Hz) activity," specifying theta power as the measure.
The text notes that "The P300 — a feedback-locked EEG response — has been suggested to reflect a bidirectional learning signal," tying the P300 component to learning/surprise-driven adjustment.
